Cliveâ€™s Album of the Year, 1989

  • Clive Murray

    Rock guitarist and gentleman adventurer from a land before time.

Clive Murray

6 April 2017 â€¢ 9 min read

In 1989 I was fifteen, and for my birthday I got my first guitar and a yearâ€™s worth of guitar lessons. Thank you eternally, Mum and Dad, RIP.

It was, it transpires, a historic turning point (yes Iâ€™m quoting Wikipedia) in politics, due to a wave of revolutions that started in Poland and swept across Europe eventually ending in the dissolution of the USSR at the end of 1991.

It was the last year of the 80s, and the last year until 2040 that, when written in Roman numerals, contains an L. Make of that what you will.

Bush Snr. entered the Oval Office, Eurosport started broadcasting, Ayatollah Khomeini really didnâ€™t like a book, the first GPS satellite went up, Iceland ended 74 years of prohibition on beer, the Purley rail crash, Exxon Valdez, Tiananmen Square, The Hillsborough Disaster (#YNWA), a tornado killed ~1300 people in Bangladesh, riots and looting in Argentina, the Game Boy was released, Voyager 2 swung by Neptune, Denmark became the first country to legally recognise same-sex union, the Guildford Four were released, and a whole lot of way more important geopolitical stuff was going on that I, as a 15-year-old, simply ignored. The reason I donâ€™t mention much of it in these things is it made no impact on me at the time.

We bade bon voyage to, among as always many others, Emperor Hirohito of Japan, Salvador DalÃ­, Ted Bundy, Sergio Leone, Mel Blanc, Laurence Olivier, Herbert von Karajan, Harry Corbett, Irving Berlin, Bette Davis and Angel Eyes (Lee Van Cleef).

Those arriving while those above were leaving included Anton Yelchin (d. 2016), Peaches Geldof (d. 2014), Daniel Radcliffe, Taylor Swift and lots of other no doubt excellent people whose names mean zero to me, but appear to be mostly sports people or reality TV people.

Musically things were pretty bloody zang all round. Iâ€™ve managed to pick a clear winner (just) but my usual shortlist of 5 has swollen to 10, and even that doesnâ€™t include Alice Cooperâ€™s Trash, W.A.S.P.â€˜s The Headless Children, eponymous debuts from Enuff Zâ€™Nuff and Extreme, It Bitesâ€™ splendid Eat Me in St. Louis, L.A. Gunsâ€™ raucous Cocked & Loaded, Little Angelsâ€™ raw and lively Donâ€™t Prey For Me or even Queenâ€™s The Miracle.

OK. Shall we?

Honourable mentions

D-A-D - No Fuel Left for the Pilgrims

It was my good old pal Stix McFlick who introduced me to this Danish 4-piece wayyyyyy back in the day, and though they never really achieved mainstream success despite slogging away through the oft-mentioned Dark Times, those who know their work will always remember the absolutely brilliant â€œSleeping My Day Awayâ€ and many others. Fun fact: Wikipedia files this album under both genres â€œHard rockâ€ and â€œCowpunkâ€. Great fun. Top track: â€œSleeping My Day Awayâ€

Electric Boys - Funk-O-Metal Carpet Ride

I remember saying once upon a time to my guitar bud Pearl Fiasco â€œyouâ€™ll never get me into that funk-metal rubbishâ€. I was wrong, on a number of counts, and this album is still one of my faves of the period and still gets regular play time. Nice big-sounding production, too. (BTW Iâ€™m really not the only one who still has a soft spot for this albumâ€¦) Top track: â€œAll Lips Nâ€™ Hipsâ€

Faith No More - The Real Thing

Itâ€™s impossible to properly explain the impact this record had at the time. Things were so simple â€“ metallers listened to Metallica, Maiden, Slayer and Megadeth and wore black leather jackets, black band t-shirts, big white trainers (for reasons that still escape me) and tight black jeans. Rockers listened to Poison, Guns N Roses, Skid Row and even Bon Jovi, and wore glammed up versions of the same uniform (ripped blue jeans, cowboy boots, slightly more colourful t-shirts). Then along came Faith No More with not only a complete lack of respect for the dress code (Jim Martin aside, obv â€“ just look at these bastards, will you?) but also a total blurring of the genre lines. Yes, I know they had been around for a while before 1989 with previous vocalist Chuck Mosley, but itâ€™s undeniable that it was The Real Thing (the bandâ€™s first release to feature mercurial maniac Mike Patton on vocals) that broke them and guaranteed the bandâ€™s place in the annals of metal. Catchy hooky choruses yet slamming metal riffs? Check. Undeniably odd metal tunes with screamed threatening lyrics? Yep. Sombre ballads? Yeah, just about. Black Sabbath cover? Oh yes. One of the tightest and funkiest rhythm sections ever to grace a tape reel? Aw yeah. Verdict: Indispensable. (Though Iâ€™m still never going to like â€œSurprise! Youâ€™re Dead!â€) Top track: â€œFalling to Piecesâ€

Kingâ€™s X - Gretchen Goes to Nebraska

Kingâ€™s X are a bit of an odd fish, band-wise. An extremely groove-adept metal power trio hailing from Springfield, Missouri, they always had some elements that sounded like nobody else. Doug Pinnickâ€™s vocals are distinctive, for sure, as is his penchant for 12-string basses (no, not with a massive neck, itâ€™s â€¦ oh just look it up), and guitarist Ty Taborâ€™s enthusiasm for altered tunings has always helped to keep their sound fresh as well. This was their second album and itâ€™s my favourite of the nine of theirs I appear to have in my library. BTW, some label Kingâ€™s X as â€œChristian Metalâ€ which is lazy and incorrect, as the bandâ€™s Christian image was in fact largely manufactured by a former manager to appeal to a crossover audience. Either way, it shouldnâ€™t matter â€“ you donâ€™t need to get kneebound to enjoy some good solid rock music. Top track: â€œOver My Headâ€

MÃ¶tley CrÃ¼e - Dr. Feelgood

Another record about which I canâ€™t be particularly objective, since it was one of my first forays into the world of hard rock proper. I remember listening to the tape in my Walkman (remember the ones that only had three buttons - Play, Stop, and Fast-forward? And if you wanted to rewind you had to flip the tape over to do it? Ask your Mum, she probably had oneâ€¦) as I went to my first job, scraping plates at Wimpy in Eastbourne for Â£1.25 an hour. I listened to it over and over and over, and loved it all. Nowadays I skip â€œWithout Youâ€ and â€œTime For Changeâ€ with an alacrity that would surprise a casual observer, but at the time I drank it all in. This was CrÃ¼e at their very best. Top track: â€œDr. Feelgoodâ€

Mr. Big - Mr. Big

Well, it was the follow-up to this that won AotY for 1991, but this is where it started. Paul Gilbert had been shredding long and hard with Racer X and was widely acknowledged as simply one of the best technical players to have ever picked up a pick, and crucially, was not a twat about it. Billy Sheehan is just Billy Sheehan, and thereâ€™s nothing you can do about that. They recruited Pat Torpey on drums and Eric Martin on vocals and put out an album that combined glam rock fun with top-drawer musicianship and itâ€™s a winner. And that opening track is still an absolute jaw-dropper. Top track: â€œAddicted to That Rushâ€

Rush - Presto

Yeah. I was surprised too, actually. Early Rush? No thanks. Canâ€™t be doing with it. Iâ€™ve tried, and Geddyâ€™s voice makes me want to start firing randomly into crowds of fluffy bunnies. But I picked this up on tape randomly one day and fell strangely in love with it. Top track: â€œScarsâ€

Joe Satriani - Flying in a Blue Dream

OK, so some might think this should win 1989, and while it is an astoundingly good and indispensable album, there are a number of things wrong with it. (Itâ€™s Joeâ€™s vocals, mainly, if weâ€™re being honest.) While I applaud the bold decision to follow 1987â€™s Surfing with the Alien â€“ a 10-track purely instrumental barnstormer that changed the musical landscape â€“ with an 18-track opus, 6 of which being vocal tracks, in hindsight Iâ€™d rather Joe had stuck to the winning formula (of course, he returned to that exact formula with spectacular results in 1992). That said, many of the instrumental tracks on here are Joeâ€™s best work ever â€“ the title track, â€œThe Forgotten pt. 2â€, â€œBack to Shalla-Balâ€, â€œThe Mystical Potato Head Groove Thingâ€ â€“ these are all incredible tracks, and no-oneâ€™s denying that. Thereâ€™s just a bit much filler in between the killers, and itâ€™s mostly the singy ones, Iâ€™m afraid. Top track: â€œFlying in a Blue Dreamâ€

Skid Row - Skid Row

Hell yes. I think my vinyl copy of this was one of my most prized possessions when I was 16 or so. I remember lending it to my first girlfriend and then getting a bit nervy when she lent it to a friend of hers to tape it. (I got it back fine without a scratch, btw.) OK, so weâ€™ve all heard â€œ18 & Lifeâ€ and â€œI Remember Youâ€ a million times, but what youâ€™ve got to remember is that this is a harder edged album that floated to the top of a sea of glam because of its heavier riffs (do excuse my metaphors) and punchier production than that of competing bands like say Cinderella or Warrant. And if you have a bad word to say about â€œYouth Gone Wildâ€, then you and I need to step outside for a moment. Top track: â€œCanâ€™t Stand the Heartacheâ€

Whitesnake - Slip of the Tongue

As the Cove himself is wont to say, â€˜Hereâ€™s a song for yaâ€™. In fact, hereâ€™s ten, and Iâ€™m willing to go on record saying that eight of them are bloody good. â€œThe Deeper the Loveâ€ can go die a hole, but then weâ€™re in 80s power-ballad country so it does come with the territory. And â€œSlow Poke Musicâ€ is justâ€¦ not very good. Everything else on here, I love. Oh, did I mention that all guitars on this album are by friend of the show Steve Vai? Well they are. Adrian Battenberg apparently injured his hand and couldnâ€™t play while they were recording the album. And apparently he injured his hand. Anyway, wrap your listening holes around â€œCheap and Nastyâ€, â€œWings of the Stormâ€, the reworked â€œFool for Your Lovingâ€, â€œJudgment Dayâ€ and the title track, and youâ€™ll be left in no doubt that youâ€™re left in no doubt. Solid throughout, and Coverdale is matchless as ever. Top track: â€œSlip of the Tongueâ€

And the winner isâ€¦

Aerosmith - Pump

OK, before we start - yes, Permanent Vacation is fine. Not much wrong with it at all. But this knocks it into a cocked chimp from a mile away.

Are you kidding me? There is a reason that the theme tune to Raw Power was â€œLove in an Elevatorâ€ for years and years. And by the way, the reason is, that song is amazing.

The album kicks off with the kick in the face that is â€œYoung Lustâ€ and doesnâ€™t let up from there. Thereâ€™s not a bad track on here, not by a long chalk. The closing ballad â€œWhat It Takesâ€ is, as mentioned par for the course, but unlike pretty much every album that followed this one, Pump is not ballad-laden. The rest of the tracks are by turns blazing rockers (â€œYoung Lustâ€, â€œMy Girlâ€), stomping riffers (â€œF.I.N.E.â€, â€œLove in an Elevatorâ€, â€œThe Other Sideâ€), bluesy groovers (â€œMonkey on My Backâ€, â€œDonâ€™t Get Mad, Get Evenâ€) and swampy atmospheric growers (â€œJanieâ€™s Got a Gunâ€, â€œVoodoo Medicine Manâ€).

10 tracks of greatness. If weâ€™ve learned anything over this series, itâ€™s that this is a winning formula for a rock album. Shame Aerosmith forgot this advice from this point forwards, really.

Get Pump. Love Pump. Be Pump.

Top tracks: â€œLove in an Elevatorâ€, â€œJanieâ€™s Got a Gunâ€, â€œYoung Lustâ€

Warrant - Dirty Rotten Filthy Stinking Rich
